events.name: Practical Security Problems and Solutions
events.description:
Currently hoping to pull off a triple header of local talent on security topics:

Title
=====
Transform your Security Practices with DevOps

Abstract
========
In a previous role I utilized DevOps practices to lead a major transformation of the security and auditing practices of our team taking them from failure-prone manual repetitive tasks to fully automated unicorn status. This talk will outline the changes we made both technically and culturally to transform not only the security team, but the whole organization into treating security as a design goal rather than an afterthought.

You‚Äôll leave this talk with a solid grasp of the tools and techniques needed to knock down the silos around your security team and enter a utopian world of security first engineering.

Bio
===
Paul Czarkowski is a recovering Systems Administrator who has run infrastructure for longer than he cares to admit. After cutting his teeth in the ISP and Gaming industries Paul changed his focus to using (and contributing to) Open Source Software to improve the Operability of complex distributed systems such as Kubernetes and OpenStack. He is currently a Developer Evangelist at Pivotal.

------------------------------------------------------------

Title
=====
AWS Role Based Security

Abstract
========
Coming Soon

Bio
===
Richard Boyd is a the CloudOpsTeam Lead at Bright Health. Besides automating all the things he enjoys interacting with the DevOps community in Austin, being a Co-Lead for his daughter's Daisy Troop, and exploring tasty breweries in ATX.

events.name: Text Processing w. Ruby - Hal Fulton (doors open @ 6:30pm)
events.description:
Love it or hate it, we all do text processing sometimes.
To do it well in Ruby, it helps to understand strings, arrays, regexes, I/O, and more topics. I'll remind you of things you forgot and teach you some new things as well. I'll end by presenting my project Livetext and showing its motivation and some of my own use cases.

# About the Speaker
Hal Fulton is the author of The Ruby Way, now in its third edition. He is working on a book Elixir for the Rubyist, to be released later in 2018. He has two degrees in computer science and more than 20 years in the industry, including a few years of teaching. His short stories have been rejected by some of the finest magazines in the country. On rare occasions he plays chess and piano, both incredibly badly. He spends his spare time putting Slinkys on escalators and passing counterfeit bills to tourists.
events.how_to_find_us: We will be at the MobilityX room, in the back of the big coworking space on the 1st floor. As the Capital Factory staff how to find us.

events.name: August: "Functional Thinking"
events.description: After an extra summer month off, we'll return with Neal Ford's 2014 "Functional Thinking: Paradigm Over Syntax". For more info, including links to where you can get your copy, see the post on our website: http://austin.computerbook.club/2018/04/01/august-functional-thinking/ ‚Äé

events.name: Learn to Code Austin: Intro to jQuery & the DOM
events.description:
Learn to Code Austin is hosting a course on jQuery and the Document Object Model. This course is open for anyone who is interested in learning about one of the most popular libraries in code today.

Register here: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/learn-to-code-austin-intro-to-jquery-the-dom-tickets-47316714567
events.how_to_find_us: **Parking in the garage at the Northshore building is $5 after 6 PM**

events.name: Code & Coffee
events.description:
We're back... Join us for another Code and Coffee bright and early!

Hang out and work on a pen, or come and talk shop with fellow web people. All are welcome, whether you‚Äôre new to development or a seasoned professional.

We‚Äôll also have breakfast tacos üåÆ and coffee ‚òïÔ∏è.

7:30 - 7:45am: Networking and Intro

7:45am - 8:30am: Lightning Talks!

8:30 - 8:45am: Wrap up

‚ùóÔ∏è‚ùóÔ∏è Important Details below...keep reading‚ùóÔ∏è‚ùóÔ∏è

We ‚ù§Ô∏è Code of Conducts, don't you? Make sure to read CodePen's before attending: https://blog.codepen.io/legal/code-conduct/

We have a new host and venue this month with The Zebra (...and they are also sponsoring the coffee!)
https://www.thezebra.com/

Food is sponsored by Media Temple (https://mediatemple.net). Media Temple is also offering all attendees 20% off any web hosting for an entire year, using coupon code CODEPENMEETUP.

Getting to the Meetup:

The Zebra is located at 98 San Jacinto Blvd #2000 (20th Floor). This building is on the southside of Cesar Chavez and San Jacinto.

The east side entrance of the building is closed for construction, so even though the address is 98 San Jacinto Blvd you'll want to enter the building via the SE corner of Cesar Chavez and Brazos. There is an entrance by the red awning next to the restaurant Forthright.

For phone map apps... it might be easier to navigate to 29 Brazos St.

There is a metered parking lot right outside of Forthright with a few spots, or there is street parking along Brazos and San Jacinto. Getting street parking is typically not a problem in the 7:30 - 8:00 range. Parking starts to charge at 8 AM, so plan to pay in advance for an hour or so of parking if you plan to stay until 9 AM.
events.how_to_find_us: We'll meet on the 20th floor, at the office of The Zebra. The building is at the SE Corner of Brazos and Cesar Chavez.

events.name: Beginner JavaScript Meetup
events.description:
Starting to code can be intimidating.

That's why Galvanize created a JavaScript fundamentals meetup that includes online content with over 30 hours of information, exercises, and projects. You don't have to go it alone. Instructional staff and fellow coders meet every Tuesday at Galvanize to go over questions and work through exercises and concepts.

JavaScript is the language of the web and the skills you will learn through this curriculum are in high demand for future developers, designers, and marketers. Level up your skills with new friends every Tuesday at 6:30 PM!

More info and sign-up here: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/learn-to-code-austin-meetup-tickets-44416542073

events.name: A Day in the Life of a Data Scientist: Panel Discussion
events.description:
Considering a career change into Data Science and want to better understand the road ahead of you? Come join us as we bring in a panel of Data Scientists and explore their backgrounds, trainings, their typical day, and problems they're solving.

Click here to sign up: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/a-day-in-the-life-of-a-data-scientist-panel-discussion-tickets-47318836915
events.how_to_find_us: **Parking in the garage at the Northshore building is $5 after 6 PM**

events.name: Ask-A-Dev: Meeting at The Central Austin Library Room 613

venue.name: Austin Central Library, Austin Public Library

events.description:
Slack Channel: https://bit.ly/2mkoEwN
‚Ä¢ What we'll do
While you can Google your way out of any problem, pairing with someone just feels better. Not all of us are fortunate enough to claim a CS degree or enjoy the guidance of a senior. We want to be the mentor we never had.

Or maybe you need a quick website for your photography portfolio but can't connect a custom domain to Squarespace. We want to help.

Come for 20 minutes. Come for three hours. Whether you're a new programmer, a veteran exploring a new language, or a tech-adverse soul lost in a sea of WYSIWYG site generators, you're among friends.

‚Ä¢ What to bring
Coming as a mentor? You'll need two hours of time, patience, and probably a laptop. Coming as a mentee? Bring anything you want to work on, and need help with!

‚Ä¢ Important to know
Code of conduct can be found: https://www.meetup.com/Ask-A-Dev/pages/25792286/Ask_a_Dev_Code_of_Conduct/
Please be sure to come out, have fun, and be respectful!
events.how_to_find_us: Use map provider of your choice. Then once inside, look for devs! Shared Learning - 207

events.name: Crush your Side Projects
events.description:
- 6 - 6:30pm: Come early to chat if you'd like
- 6:30-6:40: Set your work intentions
- 6:40-7:40pm: Focus on whatever project you want

Afterwards: Hang out with the group, grab a drink if you dare ü§ìüòà

This group serves as accountability for your solo side projects. NO RECRUITERS, NO IDEA MEN. Ty üôå

**Some example Projects our attendees have worked on:**

- Improving their personal website
- Writing a blog post
- Reading and taking notes on a book
- Working on open source projects
- Knocking out their personal todo list üòÜ

**This meetup is a good fit for you if:**

- You're looking to work on stuff outside of your fulltime work to advance your career
- You're career is accociated with tech or creative work.
- You like to talk about career advancement, entrepreneurship, self improvement
- You'd enjoy accountability for getting shit done
- You're a down-to-earth, relaxed person

This meetup aims to curate deep relationships. If you're looking to recruit, hand out business cards, or play power games, this meetup is NOT FOR YOU.
events.how_to_find_us: It's within the Thinkery plaza. Park off street or in McBee Street District Garage at $1 per hour

events.name: The Value and Benefits of Usability with Lawrence Najjar
events.description:
Need to convince other people in your organization of the value of usability? Invite them to a fun, interactive usability benefits quiz -- with a prize!

In this talk, Lawrence Najjar will share his popular usability benefits quiz. He will ask multiple-choice questions to engage participants and show just how important ease of use is for products. You write down your choices then he gives the research-based correct answers. Make a copy of the quiz to use where you work.

Bio: Lawrence Najjar is an award-winning user experience designer and researcher with extensive experience making the complex simple. He worked at small design consulting firms and large companies on enterprise applications, mobile applications, e-commerce sites, and wearable computers. He has degrees in engineering psychology from Georgia Tech, authored 100 professional papers and publications, and served on the board of the Austin User Experience Professionals Association. His personal website is http://www.lawrence-najjar.com/new-index.html

Pizza and beer will be provided thanks to our sponsor Voltage Control.

About this meetup's sponsor:

Voltage Control is bringing Jake Knapp back to Austin for a 1-day Design Sprint workshop. In this fun, fast-paced, hands-on workshop, you‚Äôll learn the Design Sprint directly from its creator. Jake will rapidly lead you through the process, teaching how the various steps fit together and why and how they work. You‚Äôll get tips and tricks beyond the Sprint book, and you‚Äôll learn how to incorporate these techniques into normal meetings. Jake will give your team a new way of looking at business challenges and the confidence to approach those challenges with renewed energy and optimism. You'll laugh. You'll high five. You'll learn ridiculously useful skills.

Get your tickets today: http://www.ticketbase.com/events/design-sprint-bootcamp-jake-knapp-voltage-control

Follow Voltage Control:
https://www.twitter.com/voltagectrl
https://www.facebook.com/voltagecontrol
https://www.instagram.com/voltagectrl/

A very grateful thank you to Rackspace for hosting!

events.name: The Austin Python Meetup Monthly Meetup
events.description:
We typically have a main presentation or a series of lightning talks, followed by discussion and Q&A. There is a diversity of domains and experience levels represented, so come with your questions and be prepared to talk about how you use Python!

The Capital Factory is now offering discounted parking in the Omni Parking lot. If you park after 6 p.m it is just $5 dollars for the night. Just remember to grab a validation ticket at the end of meetup from Capital Factory staff.
events.how_to_find_us: At the Omni hotel, go up to the 16th floor in the office tower side (not the hotel side).

events.name: The Dog Days of DevOps
events.description:
August. Summer's gotten long. The kids aren't back to school yet. People are taking vacations. It's hot. Tech meetups lag.

We have the antidote for these summer doldrums! CloudAustin's Twelve Clouds of Christmas and Dog Days of DevOps are our semiannual festive events.

We'll have a dozen (or more) 5 minute lightning demos/talks delivered by all of you! Email ([masked]) or comment below with your name and the talk's title and 1-sentence blurb to get on the list. Any cloudy, devopsey, containery, high-tech-y talk or demo is welcome.

Other user groups are invited to join us, just email us or comment below and tell us you're in, then advertise the meeting on your own meetup or whatever.

Sponsors are welcome! At 12 Clouds we have a food sponsor, treat sponsor, one or more booze sponsors, and people who have drawings for door prizes. So encourage your organization to sponsor and get goodwill from a big bunch of the best techies in the ATX.

Speakers

Name, talk title, and blurb, 5 minutes max! Anything you know, someone else doesn't and is interested in. Sign up in the comments below with name and talk title and one-sentence blurb.

1. Drew Bixby: The Dow Jones Index for Cloud Providers. A brief walk through the (free) LIFTR Index tracking the top 4 cloud providers leveraging 26 cloud metrics.

2. Jeff Carapetyan: api building is a people problem. A description of our process to build an api around our private cloud storage, and finding most challenges we're a people problem. End result, we saved big.

3. Paul Czarkowsk: "Devops is Dead, Servers are Dying, and I don't feel so great myself."

4. Philip Walenta: "The intent in user stories": Better communication means better products with fewer issues. I will be giving an example of how an ambiguous user story created more work than was needed.

5. Karthik Gaekwad: "Coolest new cloudnative security ideas and tools"

6. Harris Thayer: "MLFlow- Machine Learning in the Cloud"

7. Richard Boyd: Plumping Up Your Lamb(das) With Extra Libraries

8. Jeffery Palermo- ‚ÄúApplying 4+1 architecture to your CD pipeline‚Äù

9. Gregory Godreau: Automated iOS device provisioning in your mobile dev pipeline wit fastlane

10. Howard: "Monitoring Apps in the serverless world using Wavefront"

...

Sponsors

Because this is a large, festive event, we have room for multiple sponsors. If you have an idea of something else to sponsor tell us! Dinner, dessert, booze, and door prizes are all good.

Dinner Sponsor: Databricks (https://databricks.com/mlflow)

Location
-------------

Public parking is also available on the 7th St, Brazos St and San Jacinto Blvd.

Event Sponsors:
-----------------------
Lend'emOut (https://www.lendemout.com/) - Rent anything to/from anyone, anywhere!

FunnelAI (https://www.funnelai.com) - Connecting businesses with their prospects in real-time.

Capital Factory (https://capitalfactory.com/) - Austin's Center of Gravity for Entrepreneurs. Learn. Work. Accelerate.

Who is this event for?
------------------------------
This is a free event open for anyone interested in Austin startups.

Do you:

‚Ä¢ Want feedback on your ideas for a startup?

‚Ä¢ Want to meet people that founded/run their startups in Austin?

‚Ä¢ Want to know how startups in Austin are doing things and learn from them?

‚Ä¢ Want to discuss the challenges you are facing in your startup and get help?

‚Ä¢ Want to spread the word and get people talking about your startup?

‚Ä¢ Want to share your startup experience with newbies?

‚Ä¢ Want to help local startups with their challenges?

‚Ä¢ Just want to meet other folks involved in startups?

Then, this event is for you. You could be an entrepreneur, designer, developer...well it doesn't matter. This is open for everyone interested in Austin startups. Come, grab a drink and meet other startuppers in Austin. Exchange ideas, information, contacts, help each other and do more.

events.name: August ATX UX Book Club - Creativity, Inc.
events.description:
We will be reading Creativity, Inc. by Ed Catmull and Amy Wallace. We'll be going over Chapters 7 and 8 from the book.

About Creativity, Inc.:
A book for managers who want to lead their employees to new heights, a manual for anyone who strives for originality, and the first-ever, all-access trip into the nerve center of Pixar Animation‚Äîinto the meetings, postmortems, and ‚ÄúBraintrust‚Äù sessions where some of the most successful films in history are made. It is, at heart, a book about how to build a creative culture‚Äîbut it is also, as Pixar co-founder and president Ed Catmull writes, ‚Äúan expression of the ideas that I believe make the best in us possible.‚Äù

Here's the link to the book on Amazon: https://www.amazon.com/Creativity-Inc-Overcoming-Unseen-Inspiration/dp/0812993012/

Schedule:
6:30-7pm: Networking
7-8pm: Book Discussion

Location:
InMotion Software
11044 Research Blvd
Suite D500
Austin TX 78759

Food:
Pizza will be provided by InMotion Software.

Parking:
Since it's after hours there will be plenty of parking. It's best to park in the Building B/D garage. Please take the elevators up to the 5th Floor, and there will be signs guiding to the proper area.

Hope to see you there and happy reading!

events.name: Functional Programming Basics and React Microstates!
events.description:
1) Microstates: The React of State Management

Abstract:

When was the last time you had fun working with state?

For many, the answer is probably never, because state management in JavaScript is an endless game of compromises. You can choose to go fully immutable and write endless reducers. You can go mutable and everything becomes an observable. Or you can just go with vanilla setState and lose the benefits of serialization and time travel debugging.

Unlike the view layer, where most frameworks agree on some variation of React's concept of components, none of the current crop of state management tools strike the same balance that React components introduced to the API.

React components have a tiny API. They are functional, simple and extremely reusable. The tiny API gives you high productivity for little necessary knowledge. Functional components are predictable and easy to reason about. They are conceptually simple, but simplicity hides an underlying architecture geared for performance. Their simplicity, predictability and isolation makes them composable and reusable.

These factors combined are what make React style components easy to work with and ultimately fun to write. So why doesn‚Äôt a similar, tiny API abstracting a sophisticated architecture exist for state management? Why shouldn‚Äôt working with state be as easy and intuitive as working with React? We‚Äôll be talking about this very reasonable question, and the vision for what the ‚Äúreact of state management‚Äù would look like.

https://github.com/microstates/microstates.js

Bio:

Charles strives to make software that is a delight to use, and a pleasure to maintain. An avid contributor to open source, he founded the Frontside in 2005 to help businesses build the applications on which they base their future . Also, he really, really, really, really likes to code. Really.

2) Functional Programming Basics - Ryan Bas
Pure Functions (what are they, how do we use them)
Composition (focus on function composition)
Currying & Partial Application (how we use it, and use it in composition)
Point Free (small part as an extension of partial application)
Functor basics? ( right / left identity and associativity, and show common functors in javascript)
About Ryan-
"I've been working at Paypal for the last year on the Consumer Web Organization focusing on the Wallet and Global expansion. (React / Redux / Typescript/ Node ) Previously at a small startup in Florida in the solar energy space (Durandal / Typescript ) stack."

events.name: Budget Party
events.description:
RSVP ON EVENTBRITE:
https://www.eventbrite.com/e/budget-party-2018-tickets-47975107839

DESCRIPTION
Join us for our 3rd annual budget party!

Budget Party is a web application that teaches about Austin's city budget and invites people to remix how departments and services are funded. As city council is gearing up for this year's budget process, we are relaunching our app to better educate and understand your budget priorities.

With the help of Open Austin, Austin Tech Alliance, and the Austin Monitor, we will also be learning about participatory budgeting and how it can help bring about a more transparent, collaborative budget process. This event will be a fun and accessible way to get a glimpse into the choices that must be made when balancing Austin's budget and give you a chance to explore the ways in which the community can impact the budget.

Doors open at 5 pm, activities begin at 5:30 pm.

To join us, be sure to RSVP today!

events.name: The Heart of UX- Class 1

venue.name: Capital Factory (Located in the Austin Centre)

events.description:
We are taking UX for the People to the next level in this training! Dive deep into the heart of UX research: the ability to connect with people and understand their needs. Join us for a four-week series of engaged, hands-on learning that will deepen and strengthen your moderation skills with compassionate mindfulness techniques. This series is intended for those just beginning in UX as well as seasoned and experienced researchers as it integrates breakthrough approaches in the psychology of connection with classic methods of data collection.

What To Expect
You will have active, engaged opportunities to learn and practice. We will cover the whole process of conducting research sessions, from writing a script, to lab set-up, to moderation--the art of going off script and into the present moment! Through experiential exercises, you will learn simple, powerful connection skills that make research come alive. The series will culminate in a practice research session, in which you will have the opportunity to practice with camera and lab equipment.

Details

Instructors will include Senior researchers Jon-Eric Steinbomer and Jessica Steinbomer.

Schedule

Class 1: Research Prep and Moderation 101: Writing a Script, Lab Set-Up, The Do‚Äôs and Don‚Äôt‚Äôs of Moderating
Class 2: Experiential Learning: Converting Research Questions into Tasks, Practice with Lab Equipment, Mini-Moderation Exercises
Class 3: Depth in Connection: Tracking, Reflective Listening, and Engaged Curiosity Exercises
Class 4: Bringing it all together

*Registration required*

Want to learn more about the series or have additional questions?
Contact Jessica Steinbomer
Phone: [masked]
Email: [masked]

events.name: Austin iPhone Developer Group Meetup
events.description:
Hey Austin iOS Developers!

We're here because both Austin and iOS are awesome. We meet monthly to network, present education content, showcase apps and work, discuss iOS development, and share tip and tricks, while helping each other through bugs.

In his presentation, Nathan will show how to build eight (8) fluid interfaces covering all the major topics from the WWDC talk. You will learn the design lessons behind each interface as well as the Swift code to create them. You will learn user interface design tips and tricks which can apply to any custom UI component.

Learn how to build:
1. A calculator button
2. Custom spring animations
3. The iPhone X flashlight button
4. Rubberbanding
5. Detecting a gesture's pause similar to the iPhone X app switcher gesture
6. An interactive drawer
7. The iOS FaceTime UI
8. A rotatable view

If you are an iOS developer, then feel free to join us. Please no sales offers, recruiters, etc.

events.name: Training an AI to Recognize Cigarette Butts
Where Are the Tech Superstars?
Intro To AI and Data Science- A Look Behind the Hype (sponsored by GALVANIZE!!)
events.description:
Data Science and Machine Learning are one of the most exciting new technologies in our field, but it is also one of the most over-hyped and misunderstood. Culturally, AI is portrayed as being some sentient robotic thing that will take over humanity (lol). Even among engineers, machine learning is seen as a mysterious and endless money-making magical technology that, despite its fame, is generally not well understood by those that aren't skilled in it.

Justin Heath- cybersecurity and data science expert- will present a practical and well-grounded introduction to data science and machine learning technologies. After his talk you will be able to distinguish the reality from the hype, and you will gain exposure to the basic tools to help you get started learning more about Data Science.

This month we'd like to give a special shout-out and thanks to:

GALVANIZE!!!

They will be buying the pizza and drinks, and will be answering questions about their great courses that help you get up to speed with Data Science and other topics.

We're excited to see you all here!
events.how_to_find_us: Take the elevators on the Austin Centre side (not the Omni hotel) to the 16th floor.

events.name: Ethereum 2.0: Scaling Ethereum for the Future
events.description:
Scaling the world computer is hard. Join us in discussion around solutions for scaling Ethereum for the future.

The Ethereum network can process around 1.3 million transactions per day at a rate of 13 tx/s while VisaNet processes 150 million transactions at a rate of 1600 tx/s. How can Ethereum reach global adoption with 1/100th of Visa‚Äôs throughput? Blockchain scaling comes with a unique set of problems by the very nature of decentralization. How can Ethereum achieve scalability while remaining secure and decentralized?

We‚Äôll be discussing solutions such as sharding, side chains, off-chain computation, and state channels.

About the speaker

Preston Van Loon, Team Co-Lead @ Prysmatic Labs, Software Engineer @ Google.
Twitter: @preston_vanloon
Email: [masked]

Driven by the chance to have an impact on the world, Preston seeks challenges and solutions that can benefit everyone on a global scale. After first learning about Ethereum in early 2017, he began to explore and dive deep into Ethereum protocol. He co-founded Prysmatic Labs in January 2018. Prysmatic Labs has received grants from the Ethereum Foundation, Ethereum Community Fund, Aragon Nest, and others to enable implementation of an open source Ethereum Sharding client based on the popular client go-ethereum. He works closely with the Ethereum Research team and other clients to achieve sharding for Ethereum 2.0.
events.how_to_find_us: There is parking right next door at Mellow Johnny's, also the City of Austin Library has parking and I've listed the link below. And lastly there is a surface lot at 4th and San Antonio as well.  https://library.austintexas.gov/central/parking

events.name: SABA Presents Networking Success - Christina Bell
events.description:
Christina has over 20 years of experience in Performance Management and Development. During that time she not only worked one-on-one with employees to improve their personal performance, but also with managers to coach, mentor, and develop effective teams.

For 5 years Christina owned and managed a Sandler Training franchise. In that capacity she worked with small to mid-sized business owners to improve sales and implement strategies that impact the bottom line. It was during this time that Christina found her passion of working with entrepreneurs to help them achieve success.

SABA is committed to presenting a variety of programs that cover issues that affect our group both as small business owners and community members.

Each week we spend 30 minutes on informal, open networking. After that, our discussions rotate weekly between educational topics, non-profit speakers, speed networking, and member spotlights.

If you are interested in membership, our website is: https://southaustinbusiness.org/join/

events.name: Austin Nodejs! Save the date! Aug 15!
events.description:
Hi Austin Noders!

This meetup is rebooting like a docker container spinnin' all up in yer cloudz! Save the date for the 3rd Wed of this month, at uShip. Speaker announcements coming soon!

If you have ideas for a talk and would like to hop up to the podium, send ideas our way! Looking for talks on topics like using node for AI, ML, robots, using docker with node, code sharing with react or react-native, blockchain madness, bots, IoT, language perks and quirks, security, or any other interesting topic you'd like to share. We've got room for feature talks (30mins) and lightning talks (5 - 15 minutes) this month and next!

We'll be at uShip this month. Thanks to uShip for hosting! It's going to be a great event!

See you there!

Matt

austinnodejs.com

events.name: SABA - Close more Sales Before you Say your First Word!
events.description:
In any networking meeting or Business presentation, it starts before we say our first word, it all begins with your first impression. Make it a good one and you make a connection and are on the path to success, make a poor one and you have just created a road block for yourself, one that will take a great effort to overcome.

We make our first impression of another in a few seconds. The power of the first impression lies not in what we say but how we say it. Most people only focus on what they plan to say and not on what type of impression one makes. When you create a powerful first impression, your words will be magical to your audience.

In this presentation, LeAnn Pashina will cover 7 key techniques to use so you can supercharge your first impression. Learn how you can create a relationship with someone before you speak your first word.

SABA is committed to presenting a variety of programs that cover issues that affect our group both as small business owners and community members.

Each week we spend 30 minutes on informal, open networking. After that, our discussions rotate weekly between educational topics, non-profit speakers, speed networking, and member spotlights.

If you are interested in membership, our website is: https://southaustinbusiness.org/join/

events.name: Austin PHP Monthly Meetup
events.description:
This month we'll have Buster Neece presenting I'm a Docker Rocker and So Can You!. Says Buster:

If you're like me, all your friends are talking about Docker and what it can do. "Run faster! Jump higher! Deploy easier!" Okay, maybe it's not *all* true, but one thing definitely is: if you adopt the Docker mindset into your organization, it might make everything from your development to your testing and deployment a little easier, more predictable and more portable. Join me as I discuss the thought process and tools that I used to make understanding and using Docker so much easier, and how they can apply to you and your applications.

Join the Austin PHP Slack Channel: https://austinphpchat.com

If you are interested in sponsoring the subgroup this month, please get in touch with Ian (https://www.meetup.com/austinphp/members/72452672/).

Like us on Facebook (http://on.fb.me/AustinPHP)!

Built In Brews is a monthly happy hour co-hosted by Built In Austin and Austin‚Äôs most exciting tech companies. It‚Äôs an opportunity to network with Austin‚Äôs tech leaders, discover new career opportunities and enjoy a few beers (duh).

This month, LegalZoom invites you into its office for the latest Built In Brews.

Don‚Äôt miss the opportunity to meet LegalZoom‚Äôs team, experience the company‚Äôs culture first-hand and learn what it has in store for the future.

Drinks and appetizers will be provided. This event is for guests ages 21+. Please bring your ID and ticket to the event. By registering for this event, you are agreeing to Built In's Terms of Use (http://builtin.com/terms-use).

No staffing agencies, please.

events.name: WTD ATX August meetup: All about open source
events.description:
Join us for the August Write the Docs ATX meetup!

Open source: What it is, why you should participate, and how to get started
------------------------------------------------
When: Tuesday, August 21 @ 6:30pm
Where: Magento/Adobe, 11501 Domain Drive, Suite #150

Description
------------------------------------------------
Open source is an increasingly important (and robust) piece of the tech industry pie, especially for technical writers and developers. It can also be a great jumping-off point for learning new skills or finding new opportunities!

For our August meetup, we're excited to provide a panel of speakers discussing all things open source, including what it is, why you should participate, and how to get started.

We're thrilled to host the following speakers:
* Jeff Matthews, Documentation Manager at Magento Commerce (Adobe)
* Lori Krell, Senior Technical Writer at Magento Commerce (Adobe)

Along with providing you with an open source primer, the speakers will field your questions.

Agenda
------------------------------------------------
6:30 pm - Social and snacks
6:45 pm - Intros
7:00 - 7:45 pm - Casual panelist discussion
7:45 pm - Q&A

Speaker info
------------------------------------------------
Jeff Matthews manages a team of technical writers that support the Adobe Experience Cloud group (Magento). He has over 10 years of technical writing experience in the software industry. Jeff specializes in designing and building information development workflows and tool chains using open source tools. You can find Jeff on LinkedIn at: https://www.linkedin.com/in/jeff-matthews-52725457/.

Lori Krell works in the Adobe Experience Cloud group (Magento) as a member of the Documentation team. As a Senior Tech Writer, she develops content with Community Engineering and community contributors. Over the past few years, she has synced with customer communities to leverage their feedback and input for documentation and knowledge bases. She enjoys reaching out via webinars, live chats, and usability sessions to better understand users and deliver what they need. She lives in Round Rock in a gamer household with a wife, cat, and library. You can find Lori on LinkedIn at: https://www.linkedin.com/in/lorikrell.
events.how_to_find_us: Magento/Adobe is on the 1st floor in Suite #150. Park in the small lot directly in front of the building, or in the adjacent free Red garage (attached to the building).

events.name: Ethereum Happy Hour
events.description: Come grab a drink and talk about Ethereum!

events.name: Playing Chess & discussing programming @ Bennu (meeting #3 of 6)
events.description:
So our first meetup at Bennu was a success: not one person got out a laptop, no one really used a phone (except when we all played HQ Trivia), and we just had some really nice conversations.

I expect more of the same for meetup number two, but I'd like to do something unique for this third meetup.

So let's get together and play some Chess while we talk programming! If you don't know Chess, don't be intimidated: I or others will be more than willing to teach you, and this is all for fun! If you have a board, pieces, and clock please respond accordingly to the RSVP question, and bring them!

If things work out for it and people are interested, we'll play HQ Trivia at 8:00PM!

No rules except The Golden Rule, and please honor Bennu's 1 item minimum!

Let's have fun, see y'all there!
events.how_to_find_us: I'll be the 6'4", 300 lbs white guy wearing black glasses. I'll have a grey MacBook Pro.
